div1.head: Report: Monthly Progress Report from Lunsford D. Fricks to the Surgeon General, U.S. Public Health Service, October 6, 1924
div1.opener:
C-O-P-Y
FB
Headquarters:
Field Investigations of Malaria,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Memphis, Tennessee.
October 6, 1924. ----------
Monthly Progress Report,
September, 1924.
The Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Division of Scientific Research,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to forward herewith monthly progress report of
malaria investigations conducted during the month of September 1924, un-
der the direction of this office.

Field Laboratory, Crowley, Louisiana: Personnel - Special Expert M. A.
Barber, Assoc. San. Eng. W. H. W. Komp and Technical Assistant Theo. B.
Hayne.

Activities at the Crowley Laboratory consisted of: (1) Continuation of
work on larvicides and mosquito repellents; (2) Experiments with tallow
and lanolin as possible mosquito attractants, results negative; (3)
Study continued of effects of hydrogen-ion concentration and various foods
on the growth of Anopheline larvae; (4) Observations continued of in-
cidence of Anopheles in an irrigated region; 3,334 imagoes collected, of
which 84.1% were A. quadrimaculatus and 15.9% A. crucians; 182 bred out
from larvae and pupae, of which 17.6% were A. quadrimaculatus and 82.4%
were A. crucians; (5) Study of malaria prevalence continued by surveys of
plantations and schools and by examination of blood specimens, 128 blood
smears collected around Crowley examined, of which three were positive
P. vivax all from one negro school; (6) Special inspection by Mr. Hayne
of Paris green larvicide work at Lake City, Fla.

Memphis Laboratory: Personnel - A.A. Surgeon Wm. A. Krauss and Microscopist
Retha Kitchens.

418 blood smears were examined for malaria parasites, of which 363 were
sent in locally for diagnosis, of these 33 were positive P. vivax and 29
positive P. falc.; 32 blood smears collected in Mississippi and 17 sent in
by the Tennessee State Board of Health - each lot showing three positives
P. falc.
Monthly Progress Report
October 6, 1924.

Field Laboratory, Savannah, Ga.: Personnel - Technical Assistant Bruce
Mayne.

Mr. Mayne's activities consisted of: (1) Completion of malaria and mosquito
survey in Okefenokee Swamp; (2) A two weeks' study of mosquito production
with Mr. Gage in Aiken County, South Carolina; (3) Two lectures delivered
at the University of Georgia Medical School, Augusta, Georgia, on the entomo-
logical aspects of malaria.

list.item:
1. In his malaria survey around Billy's Island in the Okefenokee
Swamp, Mr. Mayne questioned 245 white and 190 colored persons, no
clinical malaria was observed; history of residents going back
forty years all negative for malaria contracted in the Swamp,
Anopheline mosquitoes abundant; 4,292 Anopheles collected, all
A. crucians, females greatly predominated in ratio of 130 to
one male; house infestation by A. crucians common, 520 specimens
collected from interior of one four-room house.

2. In his two weeks' study of mosquito production around impound-
ed waters in Aiken County, South Carolina, Mr. Mayne found what
appeared to be ideal Anopheles breeding and harborage conditions,
but very few Anopheline larvae or pupae, A. crucians predominated,
A. quadrimaculatus very scarce; Gambusia and predatory insects
abundant (special reports to follow).

div1.p: Epidemiological Studies of Malaria: Personnel - Asst. Surg. K. F. Maxcy.

Dr. Maxcy engaged in the study of a typhus-like disease, and was trans-
ferred to the Mexican Border early in the month.

Impounded Waters in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Epidemiologist T.H.D.
Griffitts, Asst. San. Eng. E. H. Gage and Microscopist Ethel Barrier.

Dr. Griffitts (Alabama), activities consisted of: (1) Inspection of W. H.
Hill Pond near Montgomery; 40-acre pond, no floatage, clean edges, some
grass, no mosquito production; (2) Inspection of Mitchell Dam Reservoir,
water low, banks of Reservoir clean, very little mosquito production noted;
(3) Inspection of Golden Bridge Pond, mosquito production still being con-
trolled by spraying oil; (4) Location of Gambusia hatcheries on River Falls
Power Company Project near River Falls; (5) Inspection of River Falls Power
Company Pond near Gantt, water level low, small amount of flotage, consider-
able amount of mosquito production.

Mr. Gage (South Carolina), activities consisted of: (1) Continued observa-
tions of Anopheles prevalence and distribution in Horse Creek Valley, Aiken
County, South Carolina; an increase in aquatic forms and adult Anopheles
noted during the month, but apparently not coming from large bodies of im-
pounded water; adults collected, A. crucians 27%, A. punctipennis 18% and

A. quadrimaculatus 55%, (2) Inspections of several impounded water projects
in North Carolina. Special reports to follow.

Miss Barrier (Alabama), Microscopist Ethel Barrier continued the investiga-
tion of malaria prevalence around Muscle Shoals Lake, Alabama; 176 families
consisting of 887 persons were visited during the month, 738 blood smears
collected, and a spot map completed of all houses within mosquito flight
range of Muscle Shoals Lake.

Major Drainage in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Assoc. San. Eng. A. W.
Fuchs.

Mr. Fuchs' activities consisted of: (1) Continued observations of Anopheles
production in and physical conditions of drainage ditches in Crittenden
County, Arkansas and Washington County, Mississippi; (2) Continued study of
ditch maintenance in Washington County, Mississippi, special report to
follow.

Cooperative Fish Studies: Mr. Samuel F. Hildebrand of the Bureau of Fisheries
continued the investigation of fishes in relation to mosquito control at
Augusta, Georgia. A detailed report of the season's studies will be prepared
by Mr. Hildebrand at a later date. The following is an interesting example
of his methods and observations:

A small pond containing a growth of Myriophyllum and well
stocked with Gambusia was divided into two sections early
this summer by means of a dam. Gambusia were removed from
one side and left on the other, all other conditions re-
mained the same. Twenty-four impartial dippings were made
in each pond at weekly intervals throughout the season. On
September 23rd, the following record of dippings was made:
In the control pond which contained Gambusia in 24 dips
16 Anopheles larvae were found, two were half grown, 16
Culex larvae were found, of which one was half grown, the
other larvae were all small. In the pond without n fish in
the same number of dippings. 248 Anopheles pupae or larvae
were found, consisting of two pupae, twelve large, 20 half
grown and 215 small larvae; also 834 Culex larvae or pupae
were found, consisting of 14 pupae, 47 large, 107 half
grown and 666 small larvae.

Rural Malaria Investigations: Personnel - Asst. San. Eng. J. C. Carter,
A. A. Surg. C. P. Coogle, Assoc. San. Eng. L. M. Fisher, Assoc. San. Eng.
A. W. Fuchs, Asst. San. Eng. J. G. Foster, Asst. San. Eng. H. N. Old, Asst.
San. Eng. F. R. Shaw and Surg. L. L. Williams, Jr.

Mr. Carter (Alabama) activities consisted of: (1) Study of mosquito pro-
duction around Jackson, Clarke County, continued; (2) Study of malaria

outbreak which occurred in Geneva County during August was made with a
view ti determining the relative efficiency of quinine when sold as
compared with its free distribution; (3) Study of malaria control meth-
ods by Houston County Health Officer continued; (4) Study of malaria
control methods by Barbour County Health Officer continued.

Mr. Old (Georgia) activities consisted of: (1) Continued observations
of mosquito production in Chatham County; unusually heavy rainfall from
September 16th to 30th, during which time precipitation amounted to 22.88
inches, eleven inches within 24 hours on September 16th and 17th (Record
rainfall); rainfall probably too late in summer to greatly increase mos-
quito production and malaria rate; 521 A. quadrimaculatus and 22 A. cru-
cians collected in out houses and animal sheds. City Health Officer of
Savannah states that only 25 cases of malaria reported this summer, seven
from outside the city; eight of these cases confirmed by blood examina-
tion.

Mr. Shaw (Louisiana), activities consisted of: (1) Continued study of
drainage and effects of dynamite around Patterson, St. Mary's Parish;
(2) Study of mosquito incidence around Patterson; (3) Study of drainage
and screening around Natalbany and Tangipahoa.

Dr. Coogle and Mr. Foster (Mississippi) continued the study of housing
conditions in relation to malaria in Leflore County.

Dr. Coogle's activities consisted of: Ten houses treated with creosote
oil; 151 houses inspected; 208 blood specimens collected for examination,
of which 31 were found positive. Same persons examined for enlarged
spleens, twenty-five found enlarged. A noticeable decrease in Anophe-
line prevalence was observed in Leflore County this summer. Dr. Coogle
also made malaria school surveys of three schools in Dunklin County,
Missouri; examined 96 school children for enlarged spleens, finding
eight enlarged, and collected 82 blood specimens for examination.

Mr. Foster: The twenty tenant houses screened by Mr. Foster and an equal
number of controls were kept under observation by him during the month.
The average cost of screening these tenant houses was $19.50 per house.
Mosquito counts of screened and unscreened houses have been made at week-
ly intervals - records not yet tabulated.

Mr. Fisher (South Carolina), activities consisted of: (1) Study of malaria
control methods continued in Marion, Beaufort and Charleston Counties; (2)
Observations on relative importance of A. crucians to malaria prevalence
continued in Lexington County; (3) Study of use of school census cards con-
tinued in Marion and Beaufort Counties.
Monthly Progress Report
October 6, 1924.

Dr. Williams (Virginia), activities consisted of: (1) Continued in-
vestigation of malaria prevalence and malaria control methods in
Henrico, James City, Isele of Wight, Nansemond, Brunswick, Accomac
and Northampton Counties; during the month 28,960 feet of drainage
was completed; one pond controlled (by drainage), 25 homes were screen-
ed; ten cases of malaria investigated; 24 ponds controlled by oiling;
(2) Study of control of mosquito production in Lake Prince, near Norfolk,
by changing water level apparently effective; observations, the prevail-
ing type of Anopheles in James City County continued to be A. puncti-
pennis.

Malaria Control Around U. S. Veterans' Hospitals: During the month
Asst. San. Eng. F. R. Shaw inspected mosquito control operations around
the following U. S. Veterans' Hospitals: Hospital #84, Algiers, Louisiana;
conditions extremely dry, some mosquito breeding in artificial containers-
recommended reduction of ditching crew as mosquito conditions found very
good; Hospital #74, Gulfport, Mississippi; conditions extremely dry, no
mosquito breeding, no adults found - recommended that ditching crew be
reduced at this hospital; Hospital #27, Alexandria, Louisiana; conditions
extremely dry, no mosquito breeding nor adult mosquitoes found - program
of mosquito control operations found entirely satisfactory.

Conferences and Inspections: Senior Sanitary Engineer J. A. LePrince
inspected malaria investigations being conducted in Virginia, South
Carolina, Chatham County, Georgia, Alabama, and Louisiana; also inspected
impounded water projects in Davidson County, North Carolina; and con-
ferred with State Health Officer of South Carolina.

Medical Officer in Charge in conference with state and county health
officials at Montgomery, Alabama.

Expenditures: During the month of September approximately $4,715.48
was expended from the Malaria Allotment in connection with field inves-
tigations, of malaria.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, L. D.! Fricks, Surgeon,
Medical Officer in Charge.
